Boy was this movie a stinker. The holes in the story were enormous: the main character walks freely about someone else's house and takes their horses. The moody, roll-your-eyes teenager suddenly discovers she's "the chosen one". In visiting the castle she walks into the barn and immediately goes for the stall marked "Do Not Enter". Guess what!? She's the only one able to ride the wild horse. When caught by the stable hand, is she punished? No! Of course not! She's cheerily brought to the lady of the manor. She then spends the rest of the movie randomly breaking and entering and stealing horses without consequence. The vanquishing of the evil gold-digging fiance in the end is ridiculous. It seemed like maybe the movie made sense at some point, but was edited so that each scene just ended and went to the next with no continuity. I rented this as a family movie, and we did enjoy laughing at how bad it was. Mostly it was my kids making fun of me for spending money on it.

It is not too common that a small production company makes a wonderful film with a nice story line, cast and nicely done overall. The Legend of Longwood is a wonderful dramatic story that will be enjoyed by most who sees it.

The main genre of this film is drama with a sense of adventure and fantasy thrown in. Also, they include from time to time a bit of comedy making the story enjoyable, yet thrilling.

The story begins when a young girl named Mickey (Lucy Morton) is torn away from New York where she lives with her family because they have to move to Ireland on almost the opposite side of the world. She arrives sad and depressed. To add to the problems of leaving New York, she leaves behind the memory of her passed away horse which is the only connection she has to her dad.  (If you want to find out more about he dad, you have got to watch the film!) She and her family settle in and she soon learns about a legend and starts a massive and dramatic adventure along with a discovery which leads to a very unexpected ending.

This film is a wonderful production with nicely executed shots and story plot. You never expect what happens so it is just a thrilling thing to watch. The director, Lisa Mulcahy, really excels at creating a compelling story with everything in perfect position. The only con I have is that the acting with some of the younger talent is a bit dull at times. Also, they move through conversations so fast that I missed important parts of the story, making me wondering what happened later.

My favorite scene is when a elderly lady tells Mickey the story of the, 'Mysterious Black Knight' which is a 300-year-old legend. It is shown through animated pictures and narration and becomes a very, if not the most, important part of the story.

This film really has nothing too mature for kids, so I recommend it for ages 9 to 18. I also give it 4 out of 5 stars because, although it is very nicely done in terms of directing, story and camera shots, it lacks somewhat in terms of acting skills and feels rushed at times.

The movie quality was what one would expect from a second generation European film. However, we watched it as a family, and the way it was written, you had a definite character you could hate as well as others you could relate to, and it had wild horses in it with supposed magical qualities. My daughter who is sensitive was teary-eyed at some scenes and jumping up and down in her seat at others. however, The special effects were not fabulous but with what they did, there was still a mystery/suspenseful feel to the film. I wish that the plot had been more developed with backstory about the main female character's father and his departure overseas and then disappearance, and also her friend and his dad's history. Also I was hoping at the end to have more loose ends tied up like learning more about the Black Knight.. overall, we enjoyed the film and would recommend watching it, not to say over and over again but definitely worth at least once all the way through.

A wonderful story collaboration between Irish and Dutch, that features beautiful scenery, horses, mystery, good acting and captivating family adventure.

Mickey Miller(well played by Lucy Morton), whose Irish dad has been missing in Egypt for 4 years, reluctantly moves from New York to the Irish countryside after her family inherits a mill.  Her mother(Dutch actress Thekla Reuten) and younger, slingshot fascinated, brother make the best of it, fixing up the ramshackle mill while trying to fit in.

Mickey loves horses and discover 7 white beauties, including the wildest one, Silver(Hi-ho!) at the nearby castle.  Unfortunately, the town is
haunted by the Black Knight, ancient owner of castle, and somehow, Mickey plays a role in that legend.

Everything is tip-top in this movie.  There's plenty of action and spooky, but not overbearing, mysterious going ons.  The actors are very good with fresh faces(however, if  a Harry Potter fan, you'll recognize Professor Sprout) and great outdoor shots with horses galore.

Our kids love horses and have been to Ireland, and give this flick a big thumbs up.  The extras include a making of featurette.  They shot 190+scenes in 6 weeks!  And the young actress knows how to ride.  Drama, comedy, a tiny bit of romance, and a villain to match Cruella DeVille!

There is some mysticism - fantasy - in the show, drama and a nice mystery to solve. The clues are actually large enough that the mystery is easy to solve, so no hardboiled detectives needed.

The mystery involves a 300-hundred-year-old legend of the Black Knight. The gorgeous seven white horses viewed throughout the movie are supposed to be murdered children. Don't worry folks, the legend is told in such a nice manner, even little kids should enjoy it without being too scared. Lucy Morton makes for a nice lead as Mickey, a courageous, horse-loving girl who is struggling with loss of her father and the difficulty of a move to a new (and very different) place . Brendan Conroy is excellent as Old Ben and we see too little of Miriam Margolyes as Lady Thyrza (too little for the character and too little for the plot).
